lg.l: Having seen the great city - the ancient town of Maturai
Which was eminent [with] a nature that did not know to depart [from] the city
[With] the principles in which the excellence of the sceptre, the coolness of the parasol
And the victory of the spear shone, [belonging to] the great excellence of Kauriyar
Who wields, having worn/taken on the duty of the excellent discus
[Under] the shade of Tiru who provides the [Pāṇṭiya] land,
Having entered a grove-place [in] the outerskirts of the ancient town
In which virtuous people with hearts that were intent on duty were many,
When Kōvalaṉ narrated to the lady of great penance the victory of
The Southern one [= Pāṇṭiya king] [in] faultless Maturai,
In the beautiful forest [with] a fence of cascading waters,
The first one [with respect to] the four Vedas, the one who is called Māṭalaṉ,
[With] principles that desires the goodness of having completed [all] four Vedas,
[That] sage of great tapas having circumambulated rightwards the mountain,
Having settled [= bathed] according to the [right] principles [At] the pretty, great ghat of Kumari,
He would [then] move away from] his people [= relatives].
Kōvalaṉ, going [and] bowing to the red/perfect feet
Of him who entered the place of Kavunti
In order to leave the sky-high misery of leaving [them],
Having been split [from the relatives] at the hanging grove over there,
[That] Brahmin strong [with respect to his] tongue, will narrate, having [begun to] speak:
‘The girl Mātavi, [with] a body [like] a mango shoot, who reached the great excellence [= status]
Of the king, having raised an infant [with] a mouth of milk, she having birthed [it],
After the days of impurity had gone by, [you, i.e. Kōvalaṉ] Having heard the befitting words of pleasure
[From] the great, ancient courtesan ladies, [they] saying ‘May we established
A good word [with respect to] a name for the daughter of Mātavi’,
In the middle of the darkness of night, [because of] the wavy, great ocean,
[On] a day [long] past in which my Lord [= Kōvalaṉ] was affected [= stranded] by [his] broken ship,
Because he was one who performed [the act of] auspicious charity,
As he swam for a few days, without a [clear] way of approaching [land],
[The Goddess Maṇimēkalai] saying, ‘I do not live in deviation to the commands of Intiraṉ.
I have arrived. Do not fear. I am Maṇimēkalai.
Your great charity not [still] unceasing, [you] having left [behind] sorrow,
Leave behind the miserable ocean!’ [Kōvalaṉ] saying,
Moving [me away from the ocean] like magic, give [the baby] for this reason
The name of my family God that ended [my] distress’,
[Thus], [at the exact time] when a full thousand courtesan ladies [with] beautiful girdles
Praised/blessed [the child], saying ’Maṇimēkalai’, as a shower of red-gold
Showered from [their] red hands along with the auspicious girl Mātavi,
As a fast elephant caught hold [with the trunk] of a Brahmin man [with] a body that was crooked —
A man of knowledge of the good boundaries [on] the good path of wisdom
Leaning upon a staff/crutch because of [his] weak walk, [the elephant]
Coming, while trumpeting [like] a Paṟai drum, having discarded [his] mahout,
[You, i.e., Kōvalaṉ] having taken away from the inside of the trunk
The one who was of high birth, having quickly whooped/frightened [the elephant],
[You yourself] having entered the trunk of the elephant, having hidden
Between the white tusks [on either side of] the trunk contracting [because] of false attacks,
As [you] resembled a Vidhyādhara upon a dark hill, sitting upon the nape [of its neck],
Oh, you brave one of compassion who supressed the crazed elephant bull
That did not leave [its] state of great anger! [Similarly, on another occasion,]
As a wife who was disregarded [= abandoned] [because of] the death of a baby mongoose
Despairing [and] going behind [her husband], [that] great man of the Vedas saying,
‘A life of eating [from] your hand is not dutiful/appropriate. May you give [this] good leaf
That was made [with] words in the northern language [= Sanskrit]
To people who know [their] duties.’ [She] having roamed from house to house
On the street [with] mansions [of] traders [from] great families - the street [with] shop-counters,
Saying, ‘won’t [anyone] take the fruit of absolving [my] Karma?’,
[You] calling out to, while approaching, the lady of the rare Vedas,
Saying, ‘What, pray tell, is this affliction that has possessed you?’
The beautiful [lady] declaring the sky[-high] misery that she was afflicted by,
Taking this leaf upon which was written this matter [in Sanskrit],
Giving [her] wealth [in her] hand, [she] saying, ‘may my cruel misery be eliminated’,
[He] having said, ‘Do not fear. I will eliminate your difficult misery.
May the grief in your heart leave.’ As the misery that was made [for]
Her who performed [with] the power of the fire, with the subject matter
Of the treatises that were narrated by Brahmins with [the authority of] recitation,
[They] removing the misery of her who performed charity,
[Subsequently] uniting with the husband who had gone to the forest,
[He] having given [to her] the wealth that does not weaken,
Oh, you gentleman who does not go away [= does not abandon],
Who lays the good path [for all]; [On another day],
As one lady - a wife - was victim to deceitful words [= slander],
One man who was one who was known to her husband, Who did not know [the facts], having spoken,
Lying about the evidence, ignorantly, falling into the hands
Of a spotted [= black] noose of a protective deity who consumes [such people],
[You] having seen the misery that befell the one who was hurt [= the husband],
Having reached, going quickly to the cord that tied [him up],
Saying ‘Taking my life [in] this way, give this man’s life [back].’
The good, tall, protective deity being one that did not grant [the life back],
[The Pūtam] saying, ‘There is no custom of making lose [the opportunity of]
The supreme path [to redemption] [by] taking a good [=innocent] life
For the life of an evil man. Disregard your intention.’ [Thus],
Devouring the life [of that man] in front of [him],
As [you] returned with her with a perishing heart [as her new husband],
I know [your] good Karma - the things done [in] this birth, [namely]
The excellence of the people of [her] house that [you] protected,
Having cut away the fetters of hunger of the attached relatives
For the sake of the community-people and for the connected relatives.’
[Then] asking, ‘Oh, is it you, Virutta Kōpāla! — of the returning together with
This great sapphire-creeper [Kaṇṇaki], befitting of brilliance,
Having singularly endured the killing of the fruit of [your] next birth?’
Kōvalaṉ will speak: ‘Because of a lowly man, as I mounted an animal
With horns [= a buffalo], my clothes having been taken,
In the protected palace of the guardian king, so that [my wife with]
Fragrant, five-part tresses reached [a state of] misery,
As those who cut away their fetters [of mortal life] reached their goal [= heaven]
Along with [her with] choice jewels, [with] curled tresses befitting of ornaments,
The god of desire, lamenting helplessly, throwing arrows of big blossoms
On the [now] empty earth; I saw a dream in the middle of the dark night
As though real, as Mātavi granted [= surrendered] Maṇimēkalai before
A man of Dharma [under] the beautiful, glittering Pōti [tree].
[Surely], it will happen soon over here [= on this earth].’
When the lady of great penance [Kāvunti] and the first one of the great Vedas
Told Kovālaṉ, ‘Because this abode [in] the outer boundary [of Maturai]
Is not suitable, except for to people [in] the domain of Dharma,
In the wide city, the people who come after the kind [= Vaiśyas] will take [you in]
Because of your explanation [of wanting to sell the anklet].
Leave your place here. Before the sun goes away [= sets],
Enter with your beloved lady the great city of Maturai with mansions.’
[Just then], an ancient cowherdress woman who was called Mātari,
Would walk by as is habit, having offered milk [and] cooked rice
To the Yakkiṉi [with] flower-eyes in the outskirts of the ancient town
In which the [number of] Dharmic people was many.
Having seen the mother Kāvunti, worshipping [her] feet,
[Kāvunti] being one who thought, ’There is not a single cruel thing [about]
The livelihood of cowherds who, having protected [and] guarded cows,
Distribute [their] yield. [This] ancient lady is not evil. She is perfect, she is caring.
There is no danger in placing the girl [Kaṇṇaki] [in the care of] Mātari.’
As Kāvunti said, ‘Mātari, listen. If the nobles of your clan hear of
The father of this girl’s husband, receiving [them as] guests
Of those who obtain rare wealth, they will take [Kōvalaṉ into their]
Protected houses, along with the lady with black, wide eyes.
Until [they] enter the house of wealthy people great [with] possessions,
I gave a place to stay [= refuge] to the girl from the middle-clan [= merchant clan].
Bathing the auspicious maiden in good water, applying kajal [on her]
Long eyes [like] red carps, adorning a few flowers [on her] honey-soft tresses,
Dressing [her] with pure [= clean] cloth, you becoming the mother for
Her [with] choice jewels [with] the watch of a group of companions
Of excellence of the ancient people [= good families], support [her] this way.
The lady of the earth [= earth Goddess] did not know [the suffering of]
The coloured, small feet of the lady [like] a young creeper who came with me.
For the lady with a sweet companion [like a] flower-creeper worthy of befittingness
Who did not notice her own misery, [Noticing only] for the beloved husband,
[He] reaching [a state of] trembling misery, the tongue drying [and] fading
Because of the heat of the [sun’s] cruel rays; apart from this Goddess
Who took on the duties of marrief life, for whom it was indispensible
We have definitely not seen [such a] Goddess possessing elegance!’
The skies will not fail; wealth will not know error; the victory of kings
Of the wide earth will not spoil; because [this is] the land in which
Chaste girls had been! Do you know of this good saying of that fitness?
Even if the place of refuge of people [who perform] penance is small,
It will give very great bliss. Listen to that! Inside the city [at] the gardens
[By] the Kāviri/where the forest expands, [under] the brilliant shade
That leaves commonness [behind] of the Aśoka tree [with] expanding flowers,
In front of the Cāraṇar that proclaim Dharma, having graced, seated upon
A shining, glittering, raised seat that was placed/established together
By the ascetics of the world, [was] him with a glittering body, having emitted
[light like] a bow of brilliance - him with a garland, him with a[nother] garland,
One who wore gold - him of an image/appearance that many worshipped,
That the people of the world had not [yet] seen. On one side, [his] hand
Like [the hands of] a monkey [with] black fingers, all the Jain people
Worshipping the one who stood [here], having come [as] a celestial of great victory,
Saying, ‘What is [the reason] of this one coming here/[in] this way?’
The Lord [then] speaks: ‘In the house of him who was Eṭṭi Cāyalaṉ
Into which many fasting ascetics entered, as the great lady of the house
Removed the distress of one the prominent one of great tapas
At the moment of receiving [that prominent one], one little monkey of the town
Stepping aside [and] entering in[to the house], uniting [with] the feet
Of the great man of tapas who is distinct, out of uncontainable desire
[The monkey] consuming a little of the leftovers left behind [after] having eaten
And the water that was spilled, even the knowledgeable one of unshaking tenets
Having enjoyed [this] joyful moment, saying ‘Oh lady! Protect [the monkey]
Like your [own] people!’ [The wife] having guarded [= kept] the words of truth
That were spoken by the great man; as the beloved monkey reached [its] last days,
Because she performed a saying ‘May evil be cut away’ when giving [the monkey]
An inheritance, [the monkey] becoming a son of Kauttaṉ of the north
In Varanasi in the good land of Mattimam, appearing with form [= beauty],
Brilliance and understanding, having performed many acts of great, victorious charity,
After thirty-two years have traversed, because he obtained the form of a celestial,
Saying, ‘All of the great gains of [my] prosperity that was obtained
Is [nothing but] the excellence of the charity of she who bestowed [it upon me],
She having guarded [it].’ By means of the charity of the wife of Cāyalaṉ
Who was united to the [good] principles of one part[’s worth of wealth],
Having taken the little hand of the monkey in the previous birth,
He became this form! Know this.’ As he showed [the hand] to all the Jains,
Saying, ‘A divine young man has appeared’, those that circumambulating rightwards
[the Kumaraṉ] as a rare spirit/power because of the good word
That is worthy of being befitting that was spoken by Cāraṇar,
On that day, in that city, [they being] the people of difficult penance [= ascetics],
The Jain people [with] a livelihood of restraint of them [= the ascetics],
And Eṭṭi and [his] wife of the charity that was granted,
Reached the final world of unrestrainable wealth. [Then]
Kāvunti, saying, ‘Being you who have heard [the above narrative],
You go without remaining [here] even longer, with the lady with tresses
That are full of petals.’ She who rejoiced [= Mātari], praising [Kāvunti],
At the time in which the departing heat of the sun that went along with
The lady [with] growing, young, beautiful breasts, flexible bamboo-shoulders
Sprouting, young, white teeth [and] an ancient request [= the ancient call of Karma],
As the intense voice of cows searching for [their] young ones resounded,
As a few cowherdresses with a few bangles surround the outskirts, along with
Men with a balancing pole, with a battle-axe [on] shoulders [with] lambs,
Having crossed the entrance on which fresh creepers swayed, [with]
Thickets, moats, machines [with] curved bows, black-fingered squadrons,
A sling to shoot stones, hot oil to cause distress, pots in which liquids are cooked,
A smithy of molten gold, a basket with stones, fish-hooks, [their] attachments,
A stove [in the shape of] an owl with a man’s head, forked weapons, stakes,
Sheafs for arrows, [secret] pathways, white mustard-balances,
Needles to drive [with] the hand, kingfisher[-shaped weapons] to throw speedily
Pig[-shaped weapons], bamboo [weapons], arrows of assured victory,
Staffs, distress-giving [instruments], spears and others, even the bastions being excellent,
The cowherdress-girl entered her home, having united with [good] principles.
